ground_truth: They straighten up. As Smokie stares down the rifle's barrel, he reconsiders. Spider lets go of Thao, and he and his buddies retreat to his car. Walt keeps the gun trained on them as they go. Thao rejoins his family. Walt heads back into his house. Sue, Thao, and the others go back to theirs. Walt is at the kitchen sink. Hearing something, he picks his rifle up from beside his cooker and goes out onto the porch to investigate. He looks surprised to find some of his neighbors laying gifts of food and flowers on his front steps. The Hmongs leave. Walt stares at the platters of food with distaste. He puts them all in the trash. He sees more of his neighbors approaching with gifts. He intercepts Sue and Thao. He looks sheepishly at Walt. Walt marches back to his house. Sue, her mother, and Thao get back to theirs. Sue turns back to look at Walt. Father Janovich finds Walt sitting on his porch, smoking his cigarette. Walt gets up. Father Janovich nods slightly. Walt is at the barber's. Sue is with a white boy, Trey. They approach three black youths. As the black guys hassle Sue and Trey, Walt pulls up at the junction in his pickup. Walt watches thoughtfully. Looking uneasy, Walt drives across the junction. Walt pulls up beside them. The black guys notice Walt. Walt steps out of his pickup. Chewing on a plug of tobacco, he squares up to the three black guys. He spits. Walt points his finger like a gun. He cocks his thumb. The guys hold Sue back. Walt pulls a Colt .45 pistol. Trey hurries off, and Walt puts his gun away. He turns to the black guys. He turns back to his pickup. Walt looks menacingly back at them. He gets in the truck with Sue in the passenger seat. Walt drives off in a leisurely, unhurried fashion. Walt nods thoughtfully. Walt sits down on his porch with a newspaper. He sees the elderly grandma from next door looking over at him. He picks up his glasses and puts them on to read the paper. He looks down at Daisy. Disgruntled, he looks across the street at a white woman unloading groceries from her car. She drops them. Three passing Hmong youths make no attempt to help her. One of them mimes shagging her. He sits back down as Thao helps the woman. Walt puts his glasses down and picks up a mug. He takes a drink. Walt looks over at the old lady next door, and she gives him a nod. With big buttons. Cigarettes. Walt looks furious. Walt puts away a photo of his wife.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: They tidy up. As Smokie gazes down the rifle's tube, he rethinks. Spider releases Thao, and he and his pals withdraw to his vehicle. Walt keeps the firearm aimed at them as they leave. Thao rejoins his relatives. Walt returns to his home. Sue, Thao, and the others return to theirs. Walt is at the kitchen basin. Hearing something, he grabs his rifle from beside his stove and goes out onto the porch to examine. He appears astonished to find some of his neighbors placing offerings of food and blooms on his front steps. The Hmongs depart. Walt gazes at the trays of food with repulsion. He tosses them all in the garbage. He sees more of his neighbors approaching with offerings. He intercepts Sue and Thao. He looks apologetically at Walt. Walt strides back to his home. Sue, her mother, and Thao return to theirs. Sue turns back to glance at Walt. Father Janovich discovers Walt seated on his porch, puffing his cigarette. Walt rises. Father Janovich acknowledges slightly. Walt is at the hairstylist's. Sue is with a Caucasian boy, Trey. They approach three African American youths. As the black guys pester Sue and Trey, Walt pulls up at the intersection in his pickup. Walt observes pensively. Looking uneasy, Walt drives through the intersection. Walt stops beside them. The black guys notice Walt. Walt steps out of his pickup. Chewing on a wad of tobacco, he squares up to the three black guys. He spits. Walt points his finger like a firearm. He cocks his thumb. The guys hold Sue back. Walt pulls a Colt .45 revolver. Trey scurries off, and Walt puts his gun away. He turns to the black guys. He turns back to his pickup. Walt looks threateningly back at them. He gets in the truck with Sue in the passenger seat. Walt drives off in a leisurely, unhurried manner. Walt nods thoughtfully. Walt sits down on his porch with a periodical. He observes the elderly grandma from next door looking over at him. He picks up his spectacles and puts them on to read the paper. He looks down at Daisy. Discontented, he looks across the street at a Caucasian woman unloading groceries from her vehicle. She drops them. Three passing Hmong youths make no effort to assist her. One of them mimes shagging her. He sits back down as Thao assists the woman. Walt puts his spectacles down and picks up a cup. He takes a sip. Walt looks over at the old woman next door, and she gives him a nod. With large buttons. Cigarettes. Walt looks irate. Walt puts away a photograph of his wife.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: They are straightened up. As the rifle's barrel is stared down by Smokie, reconsideration is given by him. Thao is let go by Spider, and his buddies and he are retreated to his car. The gun is kept trained on them by Walt as they go. His family is rejoined by Thao. The house is headed back into by Walt. Sue, Thao, and the others are returned to theirs. The kitchen sink is where Walt is. Hearing something, the rifle is picked up from beside the cooker by him, and the porch is gone out onto to investigate. Surprise is looked on his face as he finds some neighbors laying gifts of food and flowers on his front steps. The Hmongs leave. The platters of food are stared at with distaste by Walt. All of them are put in the trash by him. More of his neighbors are seen approaching with gifts by him. Sue and Thao are intercepted by him. Walt is looked at sheepishly by them. The house is marched back to by Walt. Sue, her mother, and Thao are returned to theirs. Walt is looked back at by Sue. Father Janovich finds Walt sitting on the porch, smoking his cigarette. The porch is gotten up from by Walt. A slight nod is given by Father Janovich. The barber's is where Walt is. A white boy, Trey, is with Sue. Three black youths are approached by them. As Sue and Trey are hassled by the black guys, the junction is pulled up at by Walt in his pickup. Thoughtful watching is done by Walt. Uneasiness is shown as the junction is driven across by Walt. The pickup is then pulled up beside them by Walt. Walt is noticed by the black guys. The pickup is stepped out from by Walt. Chewing on a plug of tobacco, the three black guys are squared up to by him. Spitting is done by him. A finger like a gun is pointed by Walt. The thumb is cocked by him. Sue is held back by the guys. A Colt .45 pistol is pulled by Walt. Trey hurries off, and the gun is put away by Walt. The black guys are turned to by him. The pickup is turned back to by him. A menacing look is given back at them by Walt. He gets in the truck with Sue in the passenger seat. A leisurely, unhurried drive off is done by Walt. Thoughtful nodding is done by Walt. The porch is sat down on by Walt with a newspaper. The elderly grandma from next door is seen looking over at him. Glasses are picked up and put on to read the paper by him. Down at Daisy is where he looks. Disgruntlement is felt as he looks across the street at a white woman unloading groceries from her car. They are dropped by her. No attempt to help her is made by three passing Hmong youths. The miming of shagging her is done by one of them. The woman is helped by Thao as he sits back down. The glasses are put down, and a mug is picked up by Walt. A drink is taken by him. The old lady next door is looked over at by Walt, and he is given a nod by her. With big buttons. Cigarettes. Furious looking is done by Walt. A photo of his wife is put away by Walt.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: They straighten up. As Smokie eyes the rifle's barrel, he reconsiders. Spider releases Thao, and they retreat to his car. Walt keeps the gun on them as they leave. Thao returns to his family, and Walt goes back home. Sue, Thao, and others return to their house. At the kitchen sink, Walt hears something, grabs his rifle, and steps onto the porch to investigate. Surprised, he sees neighbors leaving food and flowers on his steps. The Hmongs depart. Walt disdainfully discards the platters, then spots more neighbors bringing gifts and intercepts Sue and Thao. He sheepishly looks at them before returning home. Sue, her mother, and Thao go back inside; Sue glances at Walt. Father Janovich finds Walt smoking on his porch. Walt rises and the Father nods. Walt visits the barber's. Sue and Trey, a white boy, encounter three black youths. As they hassle Sue and Trey, Walt drives up, watches, and uneasily crosses the junction. He stops beside them, steps out, chews tobacco, and intimidates the black youths. Trey flees when Walt reveals a Colt .45 pistol but then holsters it. He menaces the youths, then returns to his truck with Sue, driving off leisurely. Walt considers this. On his porch with a newspaper, he sees the elderly neighbor glance over. He puts on glasses to read, looks at Daisy, then across the street where a white woman drops groceries. Three passing Hmong youths ignore her, one miming rudely, while Thao helps. Walt sips from a mug and nods to the old lady next door. Walt furiously stores away a photo of his wife.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: They straighten up. Smokie reconsiders while staring at the rifle barrel. Spider releases Thao, retreats to his car with his friends. Walt keeps the gun on them. Thao rejoins his family; Walt returns home. Sue, Thao, and others go to their house. Walt is at the sink, hears something, grabs his rifle, and finds neighbors leaving food and flowers. The Hmongs depart. Walt disdainfully trashes the food. More neighbors approach with gifts. Walt intercepts Sue and Thao, then returns home. Sue glances back at him. Father Janovich finds Walt smoking on the porch. Walt rises; Janovich nods. At the barber's, Sue with Trey encounter three black youths. Walt drives up, watches, and uneasily crosses the junction. He pulls up beside them, steps out, confronts the youths, spits, imitates a gun. Holding Sue, the youths back off. Trey flees; Walt holsters his gun, returns to his pickup. Walt drives off with Sue. Later, he sits on his porch with a newspaper, glasses on, notices the elderly neighbor. Disgruntled, he sees a woman across the street drop groceries, as Hmong youths ignore her and one mocks her. Thao helps her. Walt puts his glasses down, drinks, nods to the old lady. Furious, Walt puts away his wife's photo.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
They straighten up in unison. As Smokie peers intently down the imposing rifle's barrel, a flicker of hesitation causes him to reconsider his actions. Meanwhile, Spider releases Thao from his grasp, and both he and his companions hastily retreat to his car. With unwavering focus, Walt keeps the weapon steadily trained on them, ensuring they are well aware of his presence as they make their hasty exit. Afterward, Thao returns to the comforting embrace of his family. Walt, concluding this tense encounter, makes his way back into the familiar confines of his house. Over at the neighboring residence, Sue, Thao, and their family members return to their own home. 

In the solitude of his kitchen, Walt stands contemplatively by the sink. A faint sound catches his attention, prompting him to pick up the rifle resting beside his cooker. With curiosity piqued, he steps out onto the porch to investigate the source of the noise. To his surprise, he discovers several of his neighbors laying an assortment of gifts, including food and flowers, upon his front steps. The Hmong neighbors, their gesture complete, respectfully depart. Walt stares at the beautifully arranged platters of food with visible distaste and proceeds to dispose of them in the trash bin. 

Suddenly, he notices more neighbors approaching, bearing additional gifts. He moves decisively to intercept Sue and Thao, who appear to be involved. Walt, adopting a slightly sheepish demeanor, regards them before marching resolutely back into his house. Meanwhile, Sue, her mother, and Thao make their way back to their residence. Sue, however, turns back for a moment, casting a contemplative glance in Walt's direction.

Father Janovich finds Walt lounging on his porch, leisurely smoking a cigarette, enveloped in his contemplative cloud of smoke. Walt rises as Father Janovich approaches, offering a subtle nod in acknowledgment. Later, Walt is at the barber's, where Sue stands in the company of a young white boy named Trey. Together, they approach a group of three black youths. As the black youths begin to hassle Sue and Trey, Walt happens to be pulling up at the junction in his trusty pickup truck. Observing the unfolding scene with thoughtful consideration, he feels a sense of unease. 

Walt drives through the junction, pulling up beside the group. The black youths, noticing Walt's presence, watch him carefully as he steps out of his pickup truck. Chewing on a plug of tobacco, Walt squares up to the three black youths, taking a moment to spit on the ground with an air of defiance. He then points his finger in a mock gun gesture, complete with a thumb cock, demanding attention. As the situation unfolds, the youths hold Sue back, and in a decisive moment, Walt draws a Colt .45 pistol. Trey swiftly takes this opportunity to hurry away, leaving Walt to pocket his gun once more. Facing the black youths with firm resolve, he turns back to his vehicle. Casting one last menacing look over his shoulder, Walt climbs into the truck, with Sue now riding in the passenger seat. He drives off in a calm and deliberate manner. 

With a nod, Walt reflects on the events, settling down on his porch with a newspaper in hand. Gazing over the top of the paper, he notices the elderly grandma from next door peering at him with interest. He picks up his reading glasses and places them on the bridge of his nose to better read the paper. His eyes drift downwards to Daisy, his expression turning disgruntled. Looking across the street, he observes a white woman struggling to unload groceries from her car, only to drop them in the process. Three passing Hmong youths make no effort to lend a hand, with one audaciously miming a lewd gesture. Walt sits back, observing as Thao steps in to assist the woman. Setting his glasses aside, Walt lifts a mug to his lips, taking a calculated sip. Looking back towards the old lady next door, she acknowledges him with a nod. The scene is complete with big buttons and the distinct presence of cigarettes. Walt's fury simmers as he carefully puts away a cherished photo of his late wife, memories flooding back.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
In perfect synchronization, they adjust their postures, standing upright together. Smokie leans in, his gaze fixated on the threatening rifle’s barrel. A flicker of uncertainty crosses his mind, prompting him to reevaluate his impending actions. Meanwhile, Spider loosens his grip on Thao, releasing him, and quickly retreats, accompanied by his companions, back to the safety of his vehicle. All the while, Walt maintains unwavering concentration, keeping the weapon firmly aimed at them, ensuring they are acutely aware of his domineering presence as they make their swift departure. After this intense confrontation, Thao finds solace in the comforting embrace of his family once more. Walt, having brought this nerve-wracking encounter to a close, returns to the familiar haven of his home. Simultaneously, Sue, Thao, and their family members head back to the warmth of their own residence next door.

In the solitude and quiet of his kitchen, Walt stands thoughtfully by the sink. A faint noise draws his attention, compelling him to pick up the rifle that rests beside his cooker. With a sense of curiosity piqued, he ventures out onto the porch, eager to identify the source of the sound. To his astonishment, he finds several of his neighbors, laying an assortment of gifts upon his front steps. These offerings include an array of food and beautiful flowers. The Hmong neighbors, having completed their cordial gesture, depart with respect. Walt, with visible disdain, gazes at the artfully arranged platters of food before disposing of them unceremoniously in the trash bin.

Suddenly, his attention is drawn to more neighbors approaching, each carrying additional gifts. With decisive intent, he moves to intercept Sue and Thao, who appear to be actively involved in this neighborly gesture. Walt, adopting a slightly sheepish demeanor, regards them momentarily before turning and marching resolutely back into the confines of his house. Meanwhile, Sue, accompanied by her mother and Thao, makes her way back to their own residence. Sue, however, pauses for a brief moment, casting a contemplative glance in Walt's direction.

Father Janovich discovers Walt lounging comfortably on his porch, leisurely smoking a cigarette amidst his enveloping cloud of contemplative smoke. As Father Janovich draws near, Walt rises, offering a subtle nod of acknowledgment. Later, as the scene shifts, Walt finds himself at the barber’s shop, where Sue stands in the company of a young white boy named Trey. Together, they approach a group comprised of three black youths. As these youths begin to hassle Sue and Trey, Walt happens to arrive at the junction in his dependable pickup truck. Observing the unfolding scene with thoughtful consideration, he feels an unsettling sense of unease.

Walt navigates through the junction, pulling up alongside the group with a sense of purpose. The black youths, upon noticing Walt’s presence, watch him intently as he steps out of his pickup truck. With a plug of tobacco firmly lodged in his cheek, Walt squares up to the three black youths, taking a moment to spit defiantly on the ground. He then points his finger in a mock gun gesture, complete with a thumb cock, demanding their undivided attention. As the tense situation unfolds, the youths hold Sue back, and in a crucial moment, Walt draws a Colt .45 pistol. Sensing the opportunity, Trey swiftly hurries away, leaving Walt to return the gun to his pocket once more. Facing the black youths with firm and unwavering resolve, he turns back to his vehicle. With one last menacing glance over his shoulder, Walt climbs into the truck, now with Sue seated in the passenger seat. He drives off in a calm and deliberate manner, maintaining his composure.

With a nod to himself, Walt reflects on the day's events, settling down on his porch with a newspaper in hand. As he gazes over the top of the paper, he notices the elderly grandma from next door watching him with keen interest. Intending to better focus on the newspaper, he picks up his reading glasses and places them on the bridge of his nose. His eyes drift downward to Daisy, and his expression turns disgruntled. Looking across the street, he observes a white woman struggling to unload groceries from her car; she drops them, exasperated. Three passing Hmong youths make no effort to lend a helping hand, with one even audaciously miming a lewd gesture. Walt sits back, silently observing as Thao steps in to assist the woman. Setting his glasses aside, Walt lifts a mug to his lips, taking a calculated sip. Looking back towards the old lady next door, she acknowledges him with a nod. The scene concludes with the presence of big buttons and the unmistakable element of cigarettes. As Walt’s simmering fury bubbles beneath the surface, he carefully puts away a cherished photo of his late wife, allowing memories to flood back.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: They slowly straighten up from their positions, regaining composure. Smokie finds himself peering down the rifle's barrel; the sight causes him to reconsider his actions. Spider releases his grip on Thao, and together with his friends, he retreats, making their way to their car. Walt maintains a steady aim of the gun on them, ensuring they do not turn back as they distance themselves. As calm returns, Thao makes his way back to his family. Walt, vigilant, turns on his heel and heads back inside his house. Meanwhile, Sue, Thao, and the rest of their group return to their home as well. Once inside, Walt finds himself at his kitchen sink, attending to his surroundings. The sound of something unexpected catches his attention; responding with instinct, he picks up his rifle from its spot beside the cooker, stepping out onto the porch cautiously to investigate the cause of the noise. To his surprise, he finds some of his neighbors quietly placing gifts of food and flowers on his front steps. The Hmong visitors, having completed their offering, discreetly make their way away from his house. Walt regards the platters of food with a look of distaste, and in an expression of his discomfort, he methodically disposes of them in the trash. As he observes more neighbors approaching with additional gifts, he intercepts Sue and Thao, standing in their path. They look towards Walt sheepishly. Unwavering, Walt turns sharply, marching back towards the sanctuary of his home. Meanwhile, Sue, her mother, and Thao calmly retreat back to their own residence, though Sue allows herself a backward glance at Walt before entering her house. Later, Father Janovich comes upon Walt, who is seated on his porch with one of his cigarettes, enjoying a quiet moment. Walt acknowledges the priest by getting up, and Father Janovich reciprocates with a slight nod. Escalating to a visit to the barber's, Walt is at the scene where Sue is with Trey, a white boy, both approaching three black youths on the street. As the group of black youths begins to hassle Sue and Trey, Walt, in his pickup, arrives at the junction, observing the situation thoughtfully. Although uneasy, he initially drives across the junction, but then chooses to pull over beside the group. His presence catches the attention of the black youths, drawing their notice from Sue and Trey. Walt steps deliberately out of his pickup, his demeanor marked by the act of chewing on a plug of tobacco; he squares up to face the three black guys, creating a tense moment as he spits contemptuously. With a deliberate gesture meant to intimidate, Walt points his finger like a gun and mimics cocking it with his thumb. The black youths restrain Sue from interfering. Walt, escalating the tension, draws a Colt .45 pistol, prompting Trey to hurry off in fear. Despite the threatening display, Walt then tucks the gun away, redirecting his attention to the black youths before him. Satisfied, he turns back to his pickup truck, casting a menacing glance over his shoulder at them one final time. He gets into the truck, keeping Sue safely in the passenger seat, and drives off at a leisurely, unhurried pace, nodding thoughtfully to himself about the encounter. Back at home, Walt settles down on his porch, unfolding a newspaper to read. Looking up momentarily, he notices the elderly grandmother from the house next door observing him; he adjusts his glasses on his face to read the paper more clearly and, in a reluctant gesture, looks down at his dog, Daisy. With a hint of disgruntlement, his gaze drifts across the street to where a white woman is struggling to unload groceries from her car. The mishap causes her to drop them, and Walt watches as three passing Hmong youths fail to lend assistance, one of them even mimicking a crude gesture towards her. He remains seated as Thao steps forward to help the woman, reflecting a contrast in behavior. Walt sets down his glasses and picks up a mug, taking a drink as he looks back towards the elderly lady next door, who acknowledges him with a nod. His mind drifts to the past as he handles a photo of his late wife, the memories stirring within him even as his anger simmers beneath the surface in reaction to the ongoing changes around him.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description:
They straighten up as Smokie, reconsidering, stares down the rifle's barrel. Spider releases Thao, and he and his buddies retreat to their car while Walt keeps the gun trained on them. Thao returns to his family, and Walt goes back into his house as Sue, Thao, and the others do the same. Later, at the kitchen sink, Walt picks up his rifle upon hearing something and steps onto the porch, surprised to find neighbors leaving food and flowers on his steps. Displeased, he discards the food and intercepts Sue and Thao as more neighbors approach with gifts. Sue, her mother, and Thao return to their house after an awkward encounter.

Father Janovich finds Walt smoking on his porch, and they exchange a nod. Later, at the barber's, Sue and a white boy, Trey, encounter three black youths who hassle them. Walt watches thoughtfully from his pickup at the junction and decides to intervene. He pulls up beside the group, steps out, and confronts the youths. Walt points his finger like a gun and briefly pulls out a Colt .45 pistol before Trey hurries off. He then turns back to his pickup and leaves with Sue in the passenger seat, driving off leisurely while nodding thoughtfully.

Back home, Walt sits on his porch with a newspaper and notices the elderly grandma next door looking over. He puts on his glasses to read, watching as a white woman across the street drops her groceries. Three passing Hmong youths ignore her, but Thao steps in to help. Walt takes a drink from his mug and nods back at the old lady next door. Feeling upset, he puts away a photo of his wife after glancing at the scene across the street.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: They straighten up. As Smokie stares down the rifle's barrel, reconsidering the threat it poses, Spider lets go of Thao, and he and his buddies retreat to his car, a well-dented old Chevy that always has squealing brakes. Walt, an aging Korean War veteran whose marksmanship was once highly respected among his peers, keeps the gun trained on them as they go. Thao rejoins his family, who, like many Hmong refugees, settled in this Midwestern neighborhood after fleeing the aftermath of the Vietnam War. Walt heads back into his house, a modest bungalow that he's lived in for decades, filled with memories of his late wife. Sue, Thao, and the others go back to theirs, a small, lively home that often rings with laughter and the aroma of traditional Hmong dishes. Walt is at the kitchen sink. Hearing something, he picks his rifle up from beside his old, gas-powered cooker and goes out onto the porch to investigate. He looks surprised to find some of his neighbors laying gifts of food and flowers on his front steps, a customary gesture of apology and respect among the Hmong community. The Hmongs leave. Walt stares at the platters of food with distaste, perhaps a lingering reflection of the cultural barriers that divide them. He puts them all in the trash. He sees more of his neighbors approaching with gifts, a testament to their persistence and hope for acceptance. He intercepts Sue and Thao. He looks sheepishly at Walt, perhaps recognizing Walt’s struggles to bridge cultural divides. Walt marches back to his house. Sue, her mother, and Thao get back to theirs. Sue turns back to look at Walt. Father Janovich, the local priest who has persistently tried to engage Walt in spiritual discussions, finds Walt sitting on his porch, smoking his cigarette, a habit he picked up during his military years. Walt gets up. Father Janovich nods slightly. Walt is at the barber's, a place he visits almost religiously every month. Sue is with a white boy, Trey, who is a classmate of hers from the local high school known for its diverse student body. They approach three black youths. As the black guys hassle Sue and Trey, Walt pulls up at the junction in his pickup, the same truck he’s driven for over a decade. Walt watches thoughtfully. Looking uneasy, Walt drives across the junction. Walt pulls up beside them. The black guys notice Walt. Walt steps out of his pickup, chewing on a plug of tobacco, a habit he maintains despite the health warnings plastered on every tobacco product. He squares up to the three black guys. He spits. Walt points his finger like a gun. He cocks his thumb, a gesture loaded with the bravado from his younger days. The guys hold Sue back. Walt pulls a Colt .45 pistol, a weapon known for its reliability and power, often carried by soldiers during his era. Trey hurries off, and Walt puts his gun away. He turns to the black guys. He turns back to his pickup. Walt looks menacingly back at them. He gets in the truck with Sue in the passenger seat. Walt drives off in a leisurely, unhurried fashion. Walt nods thoughtfully. Walt sits down on his porch with a newspaper, the local paper that keeps him connected to the changing world around him. He sees the elderly grandma from next door looking over at him. He picks up his glasses and puts them on to read the paper. He looks down at Daisy, his dog, who has been his constant companion since his wife's passing. Disgruntled, he looks across the street at a white woman unloading groceries from her car. She drops them. Three passing Hmong youths make no attempt to help her. One of them mimes shagging her, a crude gesture that highlights the tensions and misunderstandings between cultures. He sits back down as Thao helps the woman, showing the respect and kindness often emphasized in his upbringing. Walt puts his glasses down and picks up a mug, savoring his evening coffee. He takes a drink. Walt looks over at the old lady next door, and she gives him a nod, a silent acknowledgment of shared history and quiet companionship. With big buttons, a reference to the oversized buttons on his flannel shirt, a staple in his wardrobe. Cigarettes linger in the air. Walt looks furious, possibly reflecting on the lost moments with his family. Walt puts away a photo of his wife, a cherished memento of a love that anchored his life.

test_cases.name: Addition (~50%)
test_cases.description: They straighten up. As Smokie stares down the rifle's barrel he reconsiders. Spider let us go of Thao and he and his buddies retreat to his car. Walt keeps the gun trained on them as they go. Thao rejoins his family. Walt heads back into his house. Sue. Thao and the others go back to theirs. Walt is at the kitchen sink. Hearing something he picks his rifle up from beside his cooker and goes out onto the porch to investigate. He looks surprised to find some of his neighbors laying gifts of food and flowers on his front steps. The Hmongs leave. Walt stares at the platters of food with distaste. He puts them all in the trash. He sees more of his neighbors approaching with gifts. He intercepts Sue and Thao. He looks sheepishly at Walt. Walt marches back to his house. Sue her mother and Thao get back to theirs. Sue turns back to look at Walt. Father Janovich finds Walt sitting on his porch smoking his cigarette. Walt gets up. Father Janovich nods slightly. Walt is at the barber's. Sue is with a white boy Trey. They approach three black youths. As the black guys hassle Sue and Trey Walt pulls up at the junction in his pickup. Walt watches thoughtfully. Looking uneasy. Walt drives across the junction. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. his every desperate step a race against time to save lives in the midst of utter devastation. On a sundappled afternoon in a quaint European village an eccentric inventor unveils a groundbreaking contraption that defies conventional physics igniting wonder and skepticism in equal measure. In a bustling marketplace in ancient Persia a cunning street thief navigates labyrinthine alleyways and vibrant bazaars. his calculated every move a daring escape from the everwatchful royal guards. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. Walt pulls up beside them. The black guys notice Walt. Walt steps out of his pickup. Chewing on a plug of tobacco he squares up to the three black guys. He spits. Walt points his finger like a gun. He cocks his thumb. The guys hold Sue back. Walt pulls a Colt 45 pistol. Trey hurries off and Walt puts his gun away. He turns to the black guys. He turns back to his pickup. Walt looks menacingly back at them. He gets in the truck with Sue in the passenger seat. Walt drives off in a leisurely unhurried fashion. Walt nods thoughtfully. Walt sits down on his porch with a newspaper. He sees the elderly grandma from next door looking over at him. He picks up his glasses and puts them on to read the paper. He looks down at Daisy. Disgruntled he looks across the street at a white woman unloading groceries from her car. She drops them. Three passing Hmong youths make no attempt to help her. One of them mimes shagging her. He sits back down as Thao helps the woman. Walt puts his glasses down and picks up a mug. He takes a drink. Walt looks over at the old lady next door and she gives him a nod. With big buttons Cigarettes Walt looks furious. Walt puts away a photo of his wife.

test_cases.name: Subject Corruption
test_cases.description: Sheep straighten up. As the kangaroo stares down the rifle's barrel, it reconsiders. The giraffe lets go of the bicycle, and it and its buddies retreat to the car. The parrot keeps the gun trained on them as they go. The bicycle rejoins its family. The parrot heads back into its house. The flamingo, the bicycle, and the others go back to theirs. The parrot is at the kitchen sink. Hearing something, it picks its rifle up from beside its cooker and goes out onto the porch to investigate. It looks surprised to find some of its neighbors laying gifts of food and flowers on its front steps. The kangaroos leave. The parrot stares at the platters of food with distaste. It puts them all in the trash. It sees more of its neighbors approaching with gifts. It intercepts the flamingo and the bicycle. It looks sheepishly at the parrot. The parrot marches back to its house. The flamingo, its mother, and the bicycle get back to theirs. The flamingo turns back to look at the parrot. The raccoon finds the parrot sitting on its porch, smoking its cigarette. The parrot gets up. The raccoon nods slightly. The parrot is at the barber's. The flamingo is with a white spider, Trey. They approach three black goldfish. As the black goldfish hassle the flamingo and Trey, the parrot pulls up at the junction in its pickup. The parrot watches thoughtfully. Looking uneasy, the parrot drives across the junction. The parrot pulls up beside them. The black goldfish notice the parrot. The parrot steps out of its pickup. Chewing on a plug of tobacco, it squares up to the three black goldfish. It spits. The parrot points its finger like a gun. It cocks its thumb. The goldfish hold the flamingo back. The parrot pulls a Colt .45 pistol. Trey hurries off, and the parrot puts its gun away. It turns to the black goldfish. It turns back to its pickup. The parrot looks menacingly back at them. It gets in the truck with the flamingo in the passenger seat. The parrot drives off in a leisurely, unhurried fashion. The parrot nods thoughtfully. The parrot sits down on its porch with a newspaper. It sees the elderly kangaroo from next door looking over at it. It picks up its glasses and puts them on to read the paper. It looks down at Daisy. Disgruntled, it looks across the street at a white octopus unloading groceries from its car. It drops them. Three passing kangaroo youths make no attempt to help it. One of them mimes shagging it. It sits back down as the bicycle helps the octopus. The parrot puts its glasses down and picks up a mug. It takes a drink. The parrot looks over at the old lady next door, and she gives it a nod. With big buttons. Cigarettes. The parrot looks furious. The parrot puts away a photo of its wife.

test_cases.name: Object Corruption
test_cases.description: They straighten up. As Smokie stares down the garden hose's nozzle, he reconsiders. Spider lets go of Thao, and he and his buddies retreat to his motorbike. Walt keeps the umbrella trained on them as they go. Thao rejoins his family. Walt heads back into his tent. Sue, Thao, and the others go back to theirs. Walt is at the kitchen counter. Hearing something, he picks his garden spade up from beside his refrigerator and goes out onto the patio to investigate. He looks surprised to find some of his neighbors laying gifts of books and paintings on his front steps. The Hmongs leave. Walt stares at the stacks of books with distaste. He puts them all in the recycle bin. He sees more of his neighbors approaching with presents. He intercepts Sue and Thao. He looks sheepishly at Walt. Walt marches back to his tent. Sue, her mother, and Thao get back to theirs. Sue turns back to look at Walt. Father Janovich finds Walt sitting on his patio, polishing his shoe. Walt gets up. Father Janovich nods slightly. Walt is at the bakery. Sue is with a white boy, Trey. They approach three black youths. As the black guys hassle Sue and Trey, Walt pulls up at the corner in his scooter. Walt watches thoughtfully. Looking uneasy, Walt drives across the corner. Walt pulls up beside them. The black guys notice Walt. Walt steps out of his scooter. Chewing on a piece of gum, he squares up to the three black guys. He spits. Walt points his finger like a wand. He cocks his thumb. The guys hold Sue back. Walt pulls a water pistol. Trey hurries off, and Walt puts his water pistol away. He turns to the black guys. He turns back to his scooter. Walt looks menacingly back at them. He gets in the scooter with Sue in the passenger seat. Walt drives off in a leisurely, unhurried fashion. Walt nods thoughtfully. Walt sits down on his patio with a magazine. He sees the elderly grandma from next door looking over at him. He picks up his binoculars and puts them on to read the magazine. He looks down at Daisy. Disgruntled, he looks across the street at a white woman unloading laundry from her cart. She drops them. Three passing Hmong youths make no attempt to help her. One of them mimes mowing her lawn. He sits back down as Thao helps the woman. Walt puts his binoculars down and picks up a teacup. He takes a drink. Walt looks over at the old lady next door, and she gives him a nod. With big knobs. Lollipops. Walt looks furious. Walt puts away a painting of his wife.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: They slump over. As Smokie peers down the rifle's barrel, he hesitates. Spider releases Thao, and he and his buddies advance to his car. Walt waves the gun around them as they leave. Thao leaves his family. Walt strolls back into his house. Sue, Thao, and the others wander back to theirs. Walt is at the kitchen sink. Hearing something, he grabs his rifle from beside his cooker and steps onto the porch to explore. He looks surprised to find some of his neighbors tossing gifts of food and flowers on his front steps. The Hmongs depart. Walt glares at the platters of food with disdain. He stacks them all in the trash. He notices more of his neighbors nearing with gifts. He greets Sue and Thao. He glances sheepishly at Walt. Walt storms back to his house. Sue, her mother, and Thao return to theirs. Sue turns back to glance at Walt. Father Janovich finds Walt lying on his porch, chewing his cigarette. Walt sits up. Father Janovich nods slightly. Walt is at the barber's. Sue is near a white boy, Trey. They approach three black youths. As the black guys surround Sue and Trey, Walt turns up at the junction in his pickup. Walt observes thoughtfully. Looking eager, Walt rolls through the junction. Walt halts beside them. The black guys spot Walt. Walt climbs out of his pickup. Chewing on a plug of tobacco, he paces up to the three black guys. He smirks. Walt waves his finger like a wand. He twitches his thumb. The guys drag Sue back. Walt brandishes a Colt .45 pistol. Trey scampers off, and Walt hides his gun. He nods to the black guys. He spins back to his pickup. Walt glares threateningly at them. He hops in the truck with Sue in the passenger seat. Walt speeds off in a leisurely, unhurried fashion. Walt shakes his head thoughtfully. Walt lounges on his porch with a newspaper. He notices the elderly grandma from next door glancing over at him. He picks up his glasses and props them on to read the paper. He stares down at Daisy. Irritated, he glances across the street at a white woman loading groceries into her car. She juggles them. Three passing Hmong youths make no effort to engage her. One of them mimics taunting her. He lies back down as Thao aids the woman. Walt places his glasses down and grabs a mug. He sips a drink. Walt peers over at the old lady next door, and she gives him a wave. With big buttons. Cigarettes. Walt looks content. Walt tucks away a photo of his wife.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: They straighten up. As Marmaduke stares down the telescope's barrel, he reconsiders. Gladiator lets go of Fern, and he and his cats retreat to his banana. Olive keeps the wrench trained on them as they go. Fern rejoins his orchestra. Olive heads back into his castle. Orchid, Fern, and the salamanders go back to theirs. Olive is at the bathroom sink. Hearing something, he picks his wrench up from beside his refrigerator and goes out onto the balcony to investigate. He looks surprised to find some of his pets laying gifts of marbles and candles on his front trampoline. The Elves leave. Olive stares at the trays of marbles with distaste. He puts them all in the compost. He sees more of his pets approaching with gifts. He intercepts Orchid and Fern. He looks sheepishly at Olive. Olive marches back to his castle. Orchid, her sister, and Fern get back to theirs. Orchid turns back to look at Olive. Brother Basil finds Olive sitting on his balcony, smoking his marshmallow. Olive gets up. Brother Basil nods slightly. Olive is at the florist's. Orchid is with a yellow giraffe, Jasper. They approach three plaid koalas. As the plaid guys hassle Orchid and Jasper, Olive pulls up at the intersection in his skateboard. Olive watches thoughtfully. Looking uneasy, Olive skates across the intersection. Olive pulls up beside them. The plaid guys notice Olive. Olive steps out of his skateboard. Chewing on a wad of licorice, he squares up to the three plaid guys. He spits. Olive points his elbow like a cannon. He cocks his knee. The salamanders hold Orchid back. Olive pulls a squirt gun. Jasper hurries off, and Olive puts his cannon away. He turns to the plaid guys. He turns back to his skateboard. Olive looks menacingly back at them. He gets in the yacht with Orchid in the passenger seat. Olive skates off in a leisurely, unhurried fashion. Olive nods thoughtfully. Olive sits down on his balcony with a novel. He sees the elderly parrot from next door looking over at him. He picks up his binoculars and puts them on to read the novel. He looks down at Snapdragon. Disgruntled, he looks across the meadow at a plaid apple unloading furniture from her wagon. She drops them. Three passing Elf worms make no attempt to help her. One of them mimes juggling her. He sits back down as Fern helps the apple. Olive puts his binoculars down and picks up a bottle. He takes a drink. Olive looks over at the old parrot next door, and she gives him a nod. With large feathers. Lollipops. Olive looks furious. Olive puts away a drawing of his goldfish.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: They straighten up. As Marvin gazes down the telescope's lens, he hesitates. Beetle releases Mia, and he and his pals drift to his scooter. Fred keeps the slingshot aimed at them as they leave. Mia reunites with her relatives. Fred strides back into his apartment. Anna, Mia, and the others return to theirs. Fred is at the living room table. Hearing something, he grabs his broom from beside his bookshelf and steps out onto the balcony to investigate. He looks astonished to find some of his neighbors placing baskets of fruit and candles on his front steps. The Hmongs depart. Fred gazes at the platters of fruit with disapproval. He discards them all in the trash. He notices more of his neighbors approaching with gifts. He intercepts Anna and Mia. He glances apologetically at Fred. Fred marches back to his apartment. Anna, her mother, and Mia return to theirs. Anna turns back to glance at Fred. Reverend Smith discovers Fred sitting on his balcony, sipping his coffee. Fred rises. Reverend Smith acknowledges slightly. Fred is at the tailor's. Anna is with a white guy, Kevin. They approach three black teenagers. As the black teens tease Anna and Kevin, Fred pulls up at the crossroads in his sedan. Fred observes thoughtfully. Feeling hesitant, Fred drives through the crossroads. Fred pulls up beside them. The black teens notice Fred. Fred emerges from his sedan. Adjusting his jacket, he faces the three black teens. He shrugs. Fred gestures with his fist. He clicks his tongue. The teens restrain Anna. Fred draws a Swiss army knife. Kevin rushes off, and Fred pockets his knife. He faces the black teens. He turns back to his sedan. Fred looks sternly back at them. He gets in the car with Anna in the passenger seat. Fred departs in a calm, relaxed manner. Fred nods thoughtfully. Fred sits down on his balcony with a magazine. He notices the elderly grandpa from next door glancing over at him. He picks up his binoculars and puts them on to read the magazine. He looks down at Bella. Annoyed, he glances across the street at a white man unloading books from his truck. He drops them. Three passing Hmong teenagers make no attempt to assist him. One of them mimics dancing with him. He sits back down as Mia helps the man. Fred sets his binoculars down and picks up a mug. He takes a sip. Fred glances over at the old man next door, and he gives him a nod. With large patches. Notebooks. Fred looks enraged. Fred stores away a photo of his sister.

test_cases.name: Object-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: They adjust their hats. As Smokie glances at the violin's strings, he rethinks his approach. Spider releases Thao, and he and his companions shuffle to his skateboard. Walt keeps the camera pointed at them as they depart. Thao reunites with his relatives. Walt strolls back into his garage. Sue, Thao, and the others head back to their porch. Walt is at the dining table. Hearing a noise, he grabs his umbrella from beside his fridge and heads out onto the deck to investigate. He looks surprised to find some of his neighbors placing offerings of toys and candles on his walkway. The Hmongs depart. Walt glares at the toys with indifference. He stows them all in the garage. He notices more of his neighbors arriving with gifts. He intercepts Sue and Thao. He looks awkwardly at Walt. Walt strides back to his garage. Sue, her aunt, and Thao retreat to theirs. Sue turns back to glance at Walt. Father Janovich finds Walt resting on his deck, sipping his coffee. Walt stands up. Father Janovich tilts his head slightly. Walt is at the bakery. Sue is with a white boy, Trey. They approach three black teenagers. As the black teens tease Sue and Trey, Walt stops at the corner in his sedan. Walt observes intently. Looking hesitant, Walt drives through the intersection. Walt stops beside them. The black teens notice Walt. Walt steps out of his sedan. Nibbling on a carrot, he faces the three black teens. He tosses it aside. Walt points his remote like a wand. He clicks his tongue. The teens restrain Sue. Walt pulls out a notepad. Trey hurries away, and Walt pockets his notepad. He turns to the black teens. He turns back to his sedan. Walt looks intimidatingly back at them. He gets in the van with Sue in the passenger seat. Walt cruises off in a relaxed, easygoing manner. Walt nods contemplatively. Walt reclines on his deck with a book. He notices the elderly grandma from next door peering over at him. He picks up his binoculars and puts them on to scan the book. He glances down at Daisy. Irritated, he looks across the street at a white woman unpacking tools from her truck. She fumbles them. Three passing Hmong youths make no move to assist her. One of them mimes serenading her. He leans back as Thao lends the woman a hand. Walt sets his binoculars down and picks up a sandwich. He takes a bite. Walt glances over at the old lady next door, and she acknowledges him with a wave. With large shoelaces. Bubblegum. Walt looks livid. Walt stows away a painting of his wife.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: They distribute sideways. As the penguin gazes up the broomstick’s handle, it reevaluates. Frog releases the balloon, and it and its toys advance to its bicycle. Chris keeps the camera balanced on them as they skip. Balloon reunites with its circus. Chris strolls forward into its igloo. Frog, Balloon, and the animals hop back to theirs. Chris is at the dining table. Smelling something, it grabs its broomstick up from beneath its refrigerator and skips out onto the dock to explore. It gazes confused to spot some of its trees placing baskets of books and pebbles on its back stairs. The robots disappear. Chris glares at the bowls of books with disapproval. It throws them all in the hamper. It notices more of its trees arriving with baskets. It confronts Frog and Balloon. It gazes bashfully at Chris. Chris ambles forward to its igloo. Frog, her parrot, and Balloon dash back to theirs. Frog turns forward to gaze at Chris. Nurse Windy discovers Chris standing on its dock, juggling its hamburger. Chris stretches up. Nurse Windy waves quietly. Chris is at the dentist’s. Frog is with a yellow frog, Jump. They skip toward three green kites. As the green toys applaud Frog and Jump, Chris rolls up at the intersection in its tricycle. Chris observes quietly. Feeling joyful, Chris rides through the intersection. Chris rolls up beside them. The green toys stare at Chris. Chris hops out of its tricycle. Laughing on a piece of soap, it spins toward the three green toys. It shouts. Chris signals with its voice like a stick. It kicks its wrist. The toys hold Frog forward. Chris spins a Hatchet .99 marble. Jump dances away, and Chris spins its marble down. It nods to the green toys. It skips forward to its tricycle. Chris laughs jubilantly forward at them. It hops in the van with Frog in the back seat. Chris pedals away in a happy, energetic style. Chris waves cheerfully. Chris jumps down on its dock with a letter. It notices the young turtle from next door turning away from it. It grabs its shoes and rolls them on to wink the letter. It gazes across at Daisy. Thrilled, it glances across the pond at a green dog tossing laundry from its nest. It catches them. Five jumping robot insects make every movement to join it. One of them mimics washing it. It jumps forward down while Balloon joins the dog. Chris spins its shoes forward and leans down a hat. It tastes a snack. Chris turns over at the young turtle next door, and it shows it a wave. With small shadows. Marbles. Chris turns delighted. Chris spins away a box of its mouse.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Smokie reconsiders as Walt aims his rifle, prompting Spider and his friends to retreat. Thao returns to his family, and Walt heads inside, where he discovers his neighbors leaving unwanted food and gifts. He discards them, intercepts Sue and Thao, and goes back to his house while they return to theirs. Father Janovich visits Walt, who is then at the barber's. Sue and Trey face harassment from black youths until Walt intervenes. He confronts the youths with a Colt .45, causing Trey to flee, and secures Sue's safety before driving off. Walt later observes his neighborhood: Thao helps a woman while others don't, earning a nod from an elderly neighbor. Frustrated, Walt puts away a photo of his late wife.
